title: I Found an Abandoned Fallout Shelter. Something TERRIFYING Was Down There.
full_text:
I'd been thinking about River's comment for three days straight. He'd mentioned it so casually, just tossed it out there while cramming for his thermodynamics exam, something about seeing this weird rusted grate behind the engineering building during one of his late night study sessions. Most people would've forgotten about it by morning, but I wasn't most people. The idea of something hidden beneath campus had been gnawing at me ever since. That's how I ended up spending my entire weekend buried in the university archives, scrolling through decades of construction records and campus development plans. Most of it was mind-numbing bureaucratic paperwork, but I'd learned to dig through the boring stuff to find the interesting bits. That's when I found the reference that made everything click into place, a brief mention in a 1961 budget report about emergency shelter construction, Cold War paranoia at its finest. The more I researched, the clearer the picture became. Riverside University had built their own little piece of the nuclear age, a fallout shelter tucked away beneath the campus where administrators and essential personnel could ride out the atomic apocalypse. The paperwork was sparse, probably classified back in the day, but I managed to piece together enough details to know I was onto something real. Finding the actual entrance took another day of careful reconnaissance. River's description had been vague. He'd just noticed something metallic gleaming near the foundation while walking back from the library. I spent hours circling the engineering building, trying to look casual while scanning every corner and shadow. Finally, spotted it tucked behind a cluster of overgrown bushes on the building's north side. The grate was exactly what River had described, rusted iron bars set into what looked like a concrete frame, partially hidden by years of accumulated debris and plant growth. Getting it open proved more challenging than I'd expected. The metal had corroded badly over the decades, and the hinges fought me every inch of the way. I'd brought a small crowbar, the kind that fits easily in a backpack, and worked at the edges methodically. Each creak and groan of stressed metal made me glance around nervously, but the area stayed empty. Students didn't usually hang around behind buildings at 2:00 in the afternoon, especially not in the dead zones between major walkways. When the grate finally gave way, it revealed exactly what I'd hoped to find, concrete stairs descending into absolute darkness. The opening was narrow, maybe three feet wide, but clearly designed for human passage. Cold air drifted up from below, carrying that distinctive underground smell of damp concrete and stagnant air. I pulled out my flashlight and checked the beam twice before committing to the descent. The stairs were solid, built to last, 12 steps down, each one carefully poured and finished despite being hidden away from any public view. Someone had taken real care with this construction, which told me the shelter below was probably the genuine article. My footsteps echoed strangely in the confined space, and I found myself moving more quietly without really thinking about it. The main shelter room opened up beyond the stairwell like stepping into a museum exhibit. My flashlight beam swept across a space that had been frozen in time for over 60 years. Everything was exactly as it should be, exactly as I'd imagined it would be based on my research. Long, metal tables arranged in neat rows, their surfaces still bearing the geometric patterns typical of early '60s institutional furniture. Folding chairs stacked against one wall, their chrome legs dulled but intact. Filing cabinets lined the far wall, their olive drab paint job screaming government issue. But it was the posters that really sold the authenticity of the place. Civil defense propaganda covered nearly every available wall surface, their bright colors faded but still legible in my flashlight beam. Duck and cover instructions illustrated with cartoon families. Radiation safety guidelines printed in that distinctive '50s graphic design style. Emergency supply checklists that read like paranoid fever dreams. Water purification tablets, radiation detection cards, instructions for decontamination procedures. I spent at least 20 minutes just documenting everything with my camera, each poster, every piece of furniture, all the emergency equipment still sitting exactly where someone had placed it decades ago. The shelter had clearly been sealed well. No water damage, minimal dust accumulation, just the slow decay of time working on materials that had been built to endure. Whoever designed this place had done their job right. The emergency supplies fascinated me most. Metal containers lined shelves along the eastern wall, their labels still readable despite the years. Water storage barrels sat in one corner, bone-dry now, but showing no signs of rust or deterioration. Medical supplies and sealed boxes, their contents probably long expired but the packaging intact. Even found a Geiger counter in its original case, the device looking like something out of a science fiction movie with its analog dials and heavy construction. Everything about the room spoke to the genuine terror people had felt during the height of the Cold War. This wasn't just bureaucratic box-checking or political theater. Someone had spent serious money and effort creating a space where human beings could actually survive nuclear fallout. The attention to detail was remarkable.... ventilation shafts built into the ceiling, communication equipment mounted on dedicated tables, even a small kitchen area with what looked like a military-grade hotplate. I was photographing the communication setup when my flashlight beam caught something that didn't fit the 1960s aesthetic. A dark opening in the far wall, maybe four feet high and just wide enough for a person to squeeze through. At first glance, it looked like it might be another ventilation shaft or utility access, but the construction was all wrong. Where everything else in the shelter showed the clean lines and smooth finishes of professional construction, this opening had rough edges and uneven stonework. The difference was immediately obvious once I focused on it. The shelter itself was all poured concrete and precision engineering. Every surface carefully finished and painted. This passage looked older, much older. The edges were cut stone rather than concrete, and the workmanship had that hand-built quality you see in much earlier construction. Someone had broken through the shelter's wall to connect it to something that had already been there. My curiosity kicked into high gear. The shelter was fascinating, but it was also exactly what I'd expected to find based on my research. This passage was something else entirely, something that wasn't in any of the university records I'd reviewed. That made it infinitely more interesting than another Cold War relic, no matter how well-preserved. I approached the opening carefully, playing my flashlight beam into the darkness beyond. The passage sloped downward at a steep angle, following what looked like natural stone stairs carved directly into bedrock. The air coming up from below felt different too, colder and somehow heavier, with an earthy smell that suggested real depth. This wasn't just a basement or utility tunnel. This was something that went down into the actual bones of the earth beneath the campus. Every rational part of my brain was telling me to document what I'd already found and get out. The shelter alone was an incredible discovery, the kind of thing that would make urban exploration forums buzz for months. I had enough photographs to prove the find and enough historical context to write it up properly. The smart thing would be to retreat, do more research, maybe come back with better equipment and a partner for safety. But rational thinking had never been my strong suit when it came to unexplored spaces. The passage was right there, clearly leading to something even older and more mysterious than the shelter. I'd come this far, spent days researching and planning, finally found something genuinely unknown. Walking away without at least seeing where it led would be like stopping a book halfway through the best chapter. I checked my equipment one more time. Flashlight was still strong. Backup batteries in my pocket. Chalk for marking my route. Phone for emergency contact if I could get signal. Everything I needed for a careful reconnaissance. I wasn't planning to go far, just enough to get a sense of what lay beyond the opening. The stone stairs were definitely hand-carved, probably dating back to the university's earliest days or even before. Each step showed tool marks where someone had shaped the rock by hand, and the wear patterns suggested they'd seen regular use at some point in the past. The passage itself was narrow enough that I could touch both walls with my arms extended, but the ceiling was high enough that I didn't need to duck. After maybe 20 steps, the character of the space changed completely. The walls went from worked stone to natural rock face, and the air grew noticeably colder. I was definitely moving deeper underground, following what seemed to be a natural fissure in the bedrock that someone had improved with those carved stairs. My flashlight beam couldn't penetrate far enough ahead to show me where the passage was leading. Just more stone walls disappearing into darkness. I started marking my path with chalk every few yards, small arrows pointing back toward the shelter. Getting lost underground was the kind of mistake that turned exploration into emergency rescue, and I had no intention of becoming that kind of statistic. The chalk marks also helped me track how far I'd gone, maybe 50 yards from the shelter when the passage branched for the first time. The branch was subtle, just a slight widening where another tunnel joined the main passage from the left. I played my light down both routes, trying to decide which way to go. The main passage continued straight ahead, following the same downward slope I'd been following. The branch seemed to level out and curve away into darkness. Both looked equally mysterious and equally dangerous. I chose to stick with the main passage, partly because it seemed like the primary route and partly because I didn't want to complicate my navigation on this first exploration. The chalk marks would get me back to the shelter, but only if I kept my route simple enough to follow in reverse. Adding side passages to the mix was a good way to get confused in the dark. The walls around me were definitely natural stone now, shaped by geological processes rather than human tools. The rock had layers and textures that spoke to millions of years of sedimentary formation. And in some places, I could see mineral veins running through the stone like frozen lightning. This was old rock, the kind of deep foundation that lay beneath most of the Midwest. Whatever I was exploring had been carved out of the Earth's actual bones. The air was getting colder with each step downward. Not just cool like a basement, but genuinely cold in a way that made me grateful for my jacket.The temperature difference suggested I was getting deeper underground, moving into spaces that never felt the warmth of surface weather. My breath wasn't quite visible yet, but it was heading in that direction. The passage curved slightly to the right, following what must've been a natural weakness in the rock. My flashlight beam swept across walls that showed no signs of recent human activity. No graffiti, no trash, no evidence that anyone else had been down here in years or possibly decades. Whatever this tunnel system was, it had been forgotten by the modern world. That's when I realized just how far I'd come from anything resembling safety. The shelter above me was already an unknown space, hidden from campus security and completely off any official map. This passage took me even further from civilization, deeper into something that might not have been explored since the shelter was built. If something went wrong down here, if I got injured or lost, nobody would know where to look for me. The smart thing would've been to turn around right then, mark the passage for future exploration with proper equipment and backup, but the tunnel kept leading downward into darkness. And my curiosity was stronger than my caution. I wanted to know where this led, what lay hidden beneath the familiar world of campus life above. The mystery was too compelling to abandon after coming this far. The passage ahead split into three different routes, each one disappearing into its own pocket of darkness. I stopped at the junction, playing my flashlight beam across each opening to get a sense of what I was dealing with. The leftmost tunnel angled sharply downward. Its floor worn smooth by what looked like centuries of water flow. The middle passage stayed level but narrowed considerably, forcing anyone who entered to walk single file. The right tunnel curved away from my light, hiding its destination completely. I chose the middle route, mostly because it seemed the most manageable. The walls pressed closer as I moved forward, close enough that I could touch both sides if I stretched my arms out. The stone here was different from what I'd seen in the main passage. Darker, with veins of some mineral that caught my flashlight and threw back tiny sparkles. Whoever had carved these tunnels had done it by hand, probably over years. The tool marks were everywhere, overlapping scratches and gouges that told the story of incredible patience and determination. Every few yards, I stopped to mark the wall with chalk. The arrows were my lifeline back to the surface, and I made sure each one was clear and visible. The last thing I wanted was to get turned around down here. The thought of wandering these tunnels until my flashlight died wasn't something I cared to dwell on, but it stayed in the back of my mind anyway. A constant reminder of how far I'd already come from anything resembling safety. The tunnel branched again, then again. Each split forced me to make another choice, and each choice took me further into a maze that was becoming more complex by the minute. Some passages were so narrow I had to turn sideways to squeeze through. Others opened into small chambers before continuing on. A few dead-ended completely, forcing me to backtrack and try a different route. The whole system felt organic, like it had grown rather than been planned, following the natural weaknesses in the rock. I found alcoves carved into the walls at irregular intervals. Most were empty, just dark recesses that vanished beyond the reach of my light. A few contained what looked like the remains of old storage, rotted wood that might've been shelving. Rusted metal brackets still anchored to the stone. One alcove held what looked like the remnants of a wooden crate, its boards warped and split with age. I didn't investigate too closely. Something about those dark spaces made me want to keep moving. The air was getting colder as I went deeper. My breath started forming small clouds in the beam of my flashlight, and the moisture I'd noticed earlier was becoming more pronounced. Water seeped through cracks in the stone, leaving dark stains on the walls and creating small puddles on the uneven floor. The sound of dripping echoed from somewhere ahead, a steady rhythm that seemed to come from multiple sources. I'd been walking for maybe 20 minutes when I heard it, a voice, faint but unmistakably human. I stopped so suddenly I nearly dropped my flashlight. The sound came from somewhere ahead, carried by the tunnel's acoustics in a way that made it impossible to judge distance. But what I heard made my stomach drop. It was a child crying for help. The voice was thin, scared, echoing off the stone walls in a way that distorted it but couldn't hide the fear. "Help me," it called, the words bouncing through the tunnels and reaching me as a series of overlapping whispers. "Please, somebody help me." I stood frozen, trying to process what I was hearing, a child down here in these tunnels. How was that possible? The entrance I'd used was hidden behind the engineering building, covered by a rusted grate that had taken effort to open. The passages I'd followed were narrow, difficult, requiring equipment and determination to navigate. No child should be down here. No child could've made it this far alone. But the voice came again, clearer this time. "Help me, please. I can't find my way out." Every rational part of my mind was screaming warnings. This wasn't right. The situation didn't make sense. But the voice was real, and it belonged to someone who was scared and lost and calling for help.I couldn't just ignore that. If there was even a chance that a child had somehow gotten lost down here, I had to do something. "Hello?" I called out, my voice echoing through the tunnels. "Can you hear me? Where are you?" The crying stopped immediately. The silence that followed was complete, broken only by the distant sound of dripping water. I waited, listening, hoping for a response that would help me locate the source of the voice. Nothing. Then after what felt like minutes but was probably only seconds, the crying started again. Same voice, same desperate plea for help, but now it seemed to be coming from a different direction. The acoustics down here were playing tricks on me, bouncing sound around in ways that made it impossible to pinpoint where it was coming from. I started moving toward where I thought the voice was strongest, marking my path with chalk as I went. The tunnel curved to the right then split again. I chose the left branch, following what sounded like the clearest path to the source of the crying. But as I moved, the voice seemed to move too, always staying just ahead of me, just out of reach. "I'm coming," I called out. "Keep talking so I can find you." The response wasn't words, just more crying, more pleas for help that echoed through the stone passages and seemed to come from everywhere and nowhere at once. I picked up my pace, moving as quickly as I dared through the narrow tunnels. The beam of my flashlight swept back and forth, searching for any sign of movement, any indication of where the child might be. The tunnels were getting more complex. What had started as a simple branching system was becoming a true maze, with passages that doubled back on themselves, chambers that opened onto multiple routes, dead ends that forced me to retrace my steps. I was marking everything with chalk, but the sheer number of turns and choices was becoming overwhelming. My mental map of the area was fragmenting, becoming less reliable with each new branch. The voice continued to call out, and I continued to follow it. But something was bothering me about the whole situation, something I couldn't quite put my finger on. The voice never got closer, no matter how far I traveled toward it. It never changed in character or tone despite the fact that I'd been responding, letting the child know that help was coming. And it always seemed to be just around the next corner, just through the next passage, leading me deeper into the maze. I stopped at another junction, this one offering four different routes. The crying was coming from the second tunnel on the right, or at least that's where it sounded strongest. But as I stood there listening carefully, I realized something that made my blood run cold. The voice wasn't getting tired. It had been calling for help for at least 10 minutes now with the same intensity, the same desperation, the same exact phrasing. A real child, scared and lost, would be getting hoarse by now, would be varying the words, trying different approaches, maybe responding more directly to my calls. This voice was like a recording, playing the same message over and over again. But that was impossible. There was no technology down here, no speakers or recording devices, just stone tunnels carved by hand decades or centuries ago. And the voice was definitely coming from ahead of me, moving as I moved, leading me deeper into the underground maze. I stood at the junction, flashlight beam playing across the four tunnel mouths, trying to decide what to do. Every instinct I had was telling me to turn around, to follow my chalk marks back to the surface, to get out of these tunnels as quickly as possible. But the voice was still calling, still pleading for help, and I couldn't shake the possibility that I was wrong about everything, that there really was a child down here who needed help and I was overthinking the situation because of the strange acoustics and my own growing fear. The crying came again, definitely from the right-hand tunnel. I made my decision and started forward, marking the wall with a clear arrow and the number four to indicate which route I'd chosen from this junction. The tunnel sloped downward and the walls pressed closer together. I had to duck my head to avoid scraping it on the low ceiling, and my shoulders brushed the stone on both sides. The voice was getting clearer, or at least it seemed that way, but it was also leading me further from any chance of easy retreat. I'd been walking for nearly 30 minutes now, following a route that twisted and turned through solid rock. Even if I turned around right now and moved as quickly as possible, it would take me at least that long to get back to the surface, and that was assuming I could follow my chalk marks correctly, assuming I didn't take a wrong turn or miss a crucial arrow in the maze of passages. The tunnel opened into a small chamber, maybe eight feet across and twice as long. Three more passages led out of it, each one disappearing into darkness. The crying was coming from the middle passage, but it sounded exactly the same as it had 20 minutes ago. Same words, same tone, same desperate plea that never varied or changed. I stood in the chamber, playing my flashlight beam across the walls and trying to think rationally about what was happening. The smart thing to do was obvious, turn around, follow my marks back to the surface and report what I'd found to someone with more experience and better equipment. Let professionals handle whatever this was.But the voice continued to call for help, and despite all my doubts and fears, I couldn't bring myself to abandon the possibility that someone really needed my help. I checked my equipment, flashlight still strong, backup batteries in my pocket, chalk supply holding up. Phone showed no signal, which wasn't surprising given how deep underground I was. I had enough supplies to continue for a while longer as long as I was careful and didn't do anything stupid. The voice called out again, and I made my choice. I marked the chamber wall with a clear indication of which passage I was taking, then stepped into the middle tunnel and continued deeper into the maze. The middle tunnel stretched ahead of me, and I pushed forward, following that persistent crying that seemed to drift through the stone like it belonged here. My chalk marks dotted the walls behind me in a trail of white arrows, each one a small promise that I could find my way back if things went wrong. The voice pulled me deeper, and I let it. Something was changing in the tunnels around me. The walls felt different now, closer somehow, even though my flashlight showed the same rough stone surfaces I'd been walking past for the last however long. Time had become elastic down here, stretching and compressing until I couldn't tell if I'd been following the voice for 20 minutes or two hours. My watch said it had been about an hour since I'd entered the middle passage at that four-way junction, but that couldn't be right. It felt like I'd walked miles. The stone pressed in on both sides of me now, close enough that I had to turn sideways in some sections. The walls seemed to pulse in my peripheral vision, expanding and contracting like they were breathing. When I turned my flashlight directly on them, they looked normal, just carved rock with tool marks and mineral veins. But the moment I looked away, that sense of movement returned. My rational mind kept insisting it was just shadows playing tricks, the way darkness always made familiar shapes look wrong. But down here, surrounded by tons of earth and rock, rational thinking felt like a luxury I couldn't afford. The child's voice echoed from somewhere ahead, bouncing off the tunnel walls in ways that made it impossible to pinpoint. "Help me, please. I can't find my way out." The same words over and over with that same desperate tone that cut straight through my chest. I'd been calling back periodically, telling the kid to keep talking, that I was coming, but the voice never responded to me directly, just kept repeating those same phrases like a mantra. Turn after turn, the tunnels branched and twisted. I marked each choice with chalk, following the voice down passages that curved back on themselves, through chambers that opened up just long enough for me to catch my breath before narrowing again. Some sections required me to duck my head. Others forced me to squeeze through gaps barely wide enough for my shoulders. The temperature had dropped enough that my breath came out in visible puffs, and the dampness in the air made everything feel clammy against my skin. My heart was pounding harder now, not just from the physical exertion, but from something else, a creeping anxiety that seemed to seep out of the walls themselves. Every shadow looked wrong. Every echo sounded like footsteps following behind me. I kept glancing over my shoulder, sweeping my flashlight back the way I'd come, but the beam only showed empty tunnel stretching back into darkness. The chalk marks were still there, white and reassuring, but they looked smaller somehow, like the darkness was already starting to swallow them. The voice came again, definitely from up ahead now, though it seemed to be coming from multiple directions at once. The acoustics down here were completely unpredictable. Sound bounced off stone surfaces and traveled through connecting passages in ways that made no sense. A whisper could seem to come from right beside your ear while a shout might sound muffled and distant. I'd lost track of how many times I thought I was getting closer to the source only to find another empty passage. I stopped at what looked like a T-junction, playing my flashlight down both options. The left passage angled downward sharply, disappearing into blackness that seemed to swallow my light. The right curved away, following what might have been a natural fissure in the rock. The voice seemed to be coming from both directions now, or maybe from neither. The echo made it impossible to tell. That's when I realized the shadows at the edge of my vision weren't staying still anymore. They moved when I wasn't looking directly at them, shifting and flowing like they had substance. I'd catch glimpses of movement in my peripheral vision, but when I turned my head, there was nothing there except empty tunnel, just stone and darkness and the steady drip of water from somewhere I couldn't see. My hands were shaking now, making the flashlight beam dance across the walls. The rational part of my brain kept trying to explain what I was experiencing, fatigue, stress, oxygen levels, the psychological effects of prolonged isolation and confined spaces. But that rational voice was getting quieter, overwhelmed by the growing certainty that something was fundamentally wrong down here. The tunnels felt alive in a way that had nothing to do with geology or engineering. I chose the right passage, marking my decision with a particularly large chalk arrow.... and continued following the voice deeper into the maze. The walls pressed closer, and I had to turn sideways again to make progress. Stones scraped against my jacket, and I could feel the weight of the earth above me like a physical presence. How far down was I now? How far from that hidden shelter entrance? The questions circled in my mind without answers. The voice called out again, clearer now, and I pushed forward with renewed urgency. Maybe I was finally getting close. Maybe there really was a child down here, lost and terrified, and all my paranoid thoughts were just the product of too much time in the dark. I called back, my voice echoing strangely in the narrow space, and hurried toward the sound. The passage opened up into another small chamber, and I swept my flashlight around the space, looking for any sign of the voice's source. Empty. Just more tunnels leading off in different directions, more choices to make, more chances to get hopelessly lost. The voice seemed to be coming from everywhere and nowhere, bouncing off the walls until it sounded like a choir of lost children all crying for help at once. That's when I saw him. A man stepped out of a side passage I hadn't even noticed, moving with calm confidence that seemed completely out of place in this underground maze. He was maybe in his 40s, average height, wearing what looked like a business suit that had seen better days. The fabric was dusty and worn, but I could tell it had been expensive once. Narrow lapels, thin tie, the kind of tailoring you saw in old movies. His hair was graying brown, styled in a way that looked neat despite everything, and his eyes were a serious blue that seemed to take in everything at once. He looked at me with an expression that was part concern, part resignation, like he'd been expecting to find me here, but wasn't happy about it. The strangest thing was how normal he seemed, how completely unaffected by the oppressive atmosphere that had been building around me for the last hour. He stood there in his dusty suit like he belonged in these tunnels, like he'd been waiting for me. "Stop following the voice," he said quietly, his words cutting through the echoing cries that still seemed to come from every direction. His voice had traces of local accent, but something older about it, like he'd learned to speak in a different time. "There's no child down here." I stared at him, my flashlight beam playing across his pale face. He didn't squint or shield his eyes from the light, just looked back at me with that same calm seriousness. The rational questions started firing in my mind. Who was he? How had he gotten down here? Why wasn't he lost like I was? But something about his presence made those questions feel less urgent than they should have. "They're trying to lure you deeper," he continued, glancing toward the passages where the voice still echoed, "into the tunnels where you won't find your way back." The way he said it, matter of fact and certain, made my skin crawl. Not because I didn't believe him, but because I did. Some part of me had been recognizing the truth of what he was saying for the last 20 minutes, even as I kept following the voice deeper into the maze. The mechanical repetition, the way it never got closer, the complete lack of human variation in the cries. I'd noticed all of it, but I'd pushed those observations aside because the alternative was admitting I'd been chasing something that wasn't real. "Who are you?" I managed to ask, my voice sounding strange in the confined space. "Tony Turner," he said, like that explained everything. "And if you go much further, you won't find your way back to the surface," the voice cried out again from somewhere in the darkness, and Tony's expression tightened slightly. He gestured for me to follow him, already turning toward a passage I hadn't seen before, moving with the kind of confidence that only came from knowing exactly where you were going. In a place where I'd been lost for an hour, following false voices and marking my path with increasingly desperate chalk arrows, his certainty was both reassuring and deeply unsettling. I hesitated for a moment, playing my flashlight over his retreating figure. The business suit, the old-fashioned styling, the way he moved through these tunnels like he'd been walking them for years, none of it made sense. But the alternative was continuing to follow a voice that apparently wasn't real, deeper into a maze I was already struggling to navigate. The crying echoed from multiple directions now, a chorus of identical pleas that made the hair on my arms stand up. Tony was already disappearing into the passage, moving with surprising speed through the darkness. I could follow him, or I could keep chasing phantom voices until my flashlight died and my chalk ran out. I made my choice and hurried after him, leaving the crying voices behind in the darkness. I stayed close behind Tony as he moved through the passage, his confident steps a stark contrast to my earlier fumbling through these tunnels. The crying voices we'd left behind in the chamber grew fainter with each step, but they didn't disappear entirely. They seemed to follow us, echoing through the stone corridors in ways that made no sense acoustically. "Don't listen to them," Tony said without turning around. His voice carried clearly in the confined space, calm and authoritative."Don't look back. And don't respond to anything you hear." I wanted to ask him what exactly we were dealing with, but something in his tone suggested this wasn't the time for questions. The way he moved through these tunnels showed an intimacy with the underground maze that went far beyond casual exploration. Every turn he took was deliberate, every choice of passage made without hesitation. He navigated like someone who had walked these routes countless times, who knew exactly where each tunnel led and which ones to avoid. The children's voices began to change as we walked deeper into the passages. What had started as simple crying and please for help evolved into something more complex. Laughter echoed from tunnels we passed by. The kind of innocent giggling that should have been comforting but instead, raised every alarm in my head. The sound bounced off the stone walls, creating an effect where it seemed to come from everywhere at once. Tony kept moving at a steady pace, never slowing, never acknowledging the sounds that grew louder around us. I tried to match his focus, keeping my eyes on his back and my feet moving forward, but the voices were becoming harder to ignore. They weren't just random children anymore. The sounds were getting more specific, more targeted. Whispers trailed just behind us, so close I could almost feel breath on my neck, words I couldn't quite make out, spoken in hushed tones that suggested secrets being shared. I fought the urge to turn around, remembering Tony's warning about not looking back. The whispers seemed to know I was listening, growing more insistent when I slowed my pace or tilted my head slightly in their direction. The tunnel system Tony led us through was even more complex than what I had experienced on my own. We passed through chambers I hadn't seen before, down passages that branched in directions I hadn't explored. Some tunnels were so narrow we had to turn sideways to squeeze through. Others opened into spaces large enough that my flashlight beam couldn't reach the far walls. Tony navigated all of it with the same unwavering confidence, never pausing to consider which way to go. I tried to keep track of our route, but the turns came too quickly and the passages twisted in ways that defeated my attempts at mental mapping. We went down stone steps carved directly into the rock through natural fissures that barely accommodated our bodies, and along corridors that showed clear evidence of deliberate construction. The variety of architecture suggested these tunnels had been built and modified over decades, maybe longer. The voices around us continued to multiply. What had started as one child crying had become a chorus of different sounds. Children laughing, children calling out, children singing songs I almost recognized but couldn't quite place. The acoustic properties of the tunnels made it impossible to determine where any of the sounds actually originated. They seemed to come from ahead of us, behind us, above us, and from passages we weren't even taking. Tony maintained his steady pace through all of it, showing no reaction to the increasing cacophony. His indifference to the sounds was almost as unsettling as the voices themselves. Either he'd grown completely accustomed to whatever was happening down here, or he was operating under a different set of rules than I was. The voices began to shift again, becoming more insistent and demanding. The children's laughter took on an edge that made my skin crawl. The whispers grew louder, more urgent, though I still couldn't make out specific words. And then something changed that made me stumble slightly in my stride. "Anthony?" The voice was clear, distinct from the chorus of children's sounds. It came from a passage to our left, echoing with perfect clarity through the stone corridors. I knew that voice. "Anthony, where are you?" River. It was definitely River's voice, calling my name with the same tone he used when he couldn't find something in our apartment. The same inflection, the same slight concern mixed with mild annoyance. It sounded exactly like him. I slowed my pace involuntarily, my head turning toward the sound before I caught myself. Tony's warning echoed in my mind, but hearing River's voice was like a physical pull. He sounded close, maybe just around the corner in that side passage. He sounded real. "Anthony, I've been looking everywhere for you. Where did you go?" The voice came again, and this time, there was worry in it, real worry. The kind River would have if he'd come home to find me missing with no explanation. "I went somewhere I shouldn't have gone," I said finally. "Saw things that changed how I think about exploration. Some places are better left alone." River waited for more, but I couldn't give him more, not without sounding delusional. "Are you okay though? Physically, I mean." "Yeah, I'm okay." He nodded slowly. "If you ever want to talk about it, whatever it was, I'm here." The offer meant more than he could know, but some experiences couldn't be shared. Some knowledge was too dangerous to pass on. I had learned that there were places in the world where the normal rules didn't apply, where something hungry and patient waited for curious people to venture too deep. That knowledge was a burden I would have to carry alone. My nightmares began in December. Always the same sequence, following those crying voices through endless branching passages, my chalk arrows disappearing from the walls, the flashlight growing dimmer with each step. Sometimes I would find myself back in that chamber where Tony Turner had first appeared, but he wouldn't be there. Just the voices multiplying and growing more desperate, more convincing. I would wake up gasping, my sheets soaked with sweat, the sound of children crying still echoing in my ears.During one particularly vivid nightmare, I dreamed that I had ignored Turner's warnings and followed the voices deeper. The tunnels kept branching, kept leading me down until I was so far beneath the Earth that my phone had no signal and my chalk had run out. When I tried to turn back, every passage looked the same. The voices laughed then, no longer bothering to mimic human distress. They had what they wanted. I woke from that dream with the absolute certainty that it had been more than imagination. Somehow, I had glimpsed what would've happened if Tony Turner hadn't intervened. I would've joined whatever collection of lost souls fed those voices, become another lure to draw future victims deeper into the maze. The thought haunted me through finals week. While other students stressed about exams and term papers, I found myself thinking about Turner's sacrifice. He had died in those tunnels in 1962, but instead of becoming part of whatever darkness lived down there, he had chosen to fight it. For 60 years, he had been protecting people, guiding them back to safety when they wandered too far into that underground trap. How many others had he saved? How many curious explorers, maintenance workers, or lost students had encountered those voices over the decades? Turner had given up any chance of rest or peace to stand guard against something that fed on human curiosity and compassion. The magnitude of that sacrifice was staggering. Spring semester arrived, and with it came a new crop of urban exploration enthusiasts. I watched them in online forums sharing photos of abandoned buildings and discussing potential sites. Several mentioned the campus, speculating about tunnels and hidden spaces. Each post made my stomach tighten. I wanted to warn them all, but how could I do it without revealing too much? How could I protect them without putting myself at risk? The solution came to me gradually. I began participating in forum discussions again, but only to steer people away from certain areas. When someone posted about underground exploration near universities, I would mention safety concerns, suggest better sites elsewhere, emphasize the legal risks of trespassing on campus property. I became known as the cautious voice in the community, the one who always advocated for proper permits and official access. Some people listened. Others dismissed my warnings as overcautiousness. But I kept posting, kept trying to redirect curiosity towards safer outlets. It wasn't much, but it was something, a small way of honoring Turner's protection by extending it to others. My own relationship with exploration had changed permanently. The passion that had once driven me to seek out hidden places was gone, replaced by a deep wariness of forgotten spaces. I still felt the pull sometimes, the old excitement when I glimpsed a promising doorway or heard rumors of abandoned tunnels. But now, that excitement was tempered by the knowledge of what might be waiting in the darkness. I completed my degree at Riverside University that spring, walking across the stage to receive my diploma while carefully avoiding eye contact with the engineering building in the distance. During the ceremony, I thought about Turner again. Was he still down there? Still protecting people who wandered into those tunnels? Did he know that someone finally understood what he had sacrificed? Did it matter to him that his heroism was remembered, even if it could never be officially acknowledged? After graduation, I moved away from Riverside, taking a job in a city where the buildings were newer and the underground infrastructure was well-mapped and maintained. But I never forgot those tunnels or the man who had saved my life in them. Sometimes late at night, I would think about other hidden places around the world, other forgotten spaces where curious people might venture. I wondered if Turner was unique or if there were others like him, guardians standing watch in the darkness, protecting the living from things that should not be. The nightmares faded over time, but they never completely disappeared. Once or twice a month, I would dream of tunnels and voices, of chalk arrows that led nowhere and lights that failed at the worst possible moment. But now, Turner was always there in those dreams, emerging from the shadows with his calm authority and serious blue eyes. Even in sleep, he continued to guide me to safety. I learned to live with the knowledge of what existed beneath that campus. Some doors should never be opened. Some places were meant to remain forgotten. But I also learned that even in the darkest spaces, there could be guardians, heroes who chose to stand against the darkness rather than surrender to it. Turner had saved more than my life that night. He had shown me that some mysteries were too dangerous to pursue, that curiosity without wisdom could lead to destruction. It was a hard lesson, one that had cost me my passion for exploration, but it was also a necessary one. Some places were meant to remain hidden, and some people were brave enough to make sure they stayed that way. The phone call came on a Tuesday morning in March, three years after I'd graduated from Riverside University. I was sitting at my kitchen table in my apartment downtown, scrolling through news headlines while my coffee cooled when my phone buzzed with a number I didn't recognize. "Anthony Meyer?" The voice was unfamiliar, professional.Yeah. That's me. This is Detective Sarah Hoffman with the Riverside Police Department. I'm calling about a missing person case. Your name came up in our investigation. My stomach dropped. The coffee mug felt suddenly heavy in my hands. Missing person? A student named Marcus Chen, he disappeared three days ago. According to his roommate, he mentioned your name before he went missing, said you'd warned him about something on campus. Marcus. I remembered him from the library, remembered the way his eyes had lit up when I'd tried to warn him away from the engineering building. I'd seen that same curiosity in my own reflection once, that hunger for hidden places and forgotten secrets, the hunger that had nearly killed me. "I haven't spoken to Marcus in years," I said, which was true. "What happened?" "His roommate says he was obsessed with exploring campus infrastructure, tunnels, maintenance areas, that sort of thing. Ring any bells?" Everything about it rang bells. The detective's words brought back the weight of those stone passages, the echo of children's voices calling from the darkness, the feeling of being watched by something that wanted to drag me deeper into places where no one would ever find me. I closed my eyes and saw Tony Turner's serious face, his dusty business suit, the way he'd moved through those tunnels like he'd been walking them for decades, which I supposed he had been. "Detective, where exactly did Marcus disappear?" "Near the engineering building. Campus security found his backpack behind the building along with some tools. Looks like he was trying to access something." The grate. Marcus had found the grate, just like I had, just like Tony Turner had 61 years ago when he was still alive and still thought he could handle whatever was waiting in the dark. "I need to tell you something," I said. "But you're not going to believe it." Detective Hoffman listened while I explained about the tunnels, about the voices that mimicked people you cared about, about the way the passages twisted and branched until you couldn't find your way back. I didn't mention Tony Turner. That part of the story felt too personal, too impossible to share with someone who hadn't been there. Instead, I focused on the danger, on the way the tunnels could trap someone who went in unprepared. "Mr. Meyer," she said when I finished, "Are you saying you think Marcus is still down there?" "I'm saying those tunnels are dangerous, more dangerous than anyone realizes. If Marcus went in alone..." I didn't finish the sentence, didn't want to think about Marcus wandering through those stone passages, following voices that sounded like his friends, his family, while something malevolent led him deeper and deeper until his flashlight died and he was lost forever in the dark. After I hung up, I sat at my kitchen table for a long time, staring at my phone. Three years had passed since I'd crawled out of that grate and sworn I'd never go back. Three years of avoiding abandoned buildings, of taking well-lit routes through familiar streets, of keeping my camera in its case because the thought of exploring dark places made my hands shake. But Marcus was down there, a kid who'd asked the wrong questions and ignored the right warnings, just like I had. I opened my laptop and booked a flight to Riverside. The campus looked the same when I arrived that evening. Same brick buildings, same tree-lined paths, same clusters of students hurrying between classes with backpacks slung over their shoulders. I'd driven straight from the airport to the university, not bothering to check into a hotel first. The engineering building sat exactly where I remembered it, its windows glowing yellow in the gathering dusk. I parked across the street and walked around to the north side of the building. The bushes had grown thicker in the three years since I'd been here, creating better cover for the iron grate. I pushed through the branches and found it exactly as I'd left it. The metal still corroded and stained, the concrete frame still cracked from decades of weather. Someone had forced it open recently. The rust flakes around the edges were fresh, and I could see scratches in the metal where tools had been applied. Marcus's tools probably, the same kind of small crowbar I'd used when I was stupid enough to think curiosity was worth any risk. I knelt beside the opening and shone my phone's flashlight down the concrete stairs. The beam barely penetrated the darkness below, but I could see the first few steps, the same carefully constructed descent that led to the Cold War shelter. Somewhere beyond that, past the broken wall and through the stone passages, Marcus was either still alive and terrified or he was something else entirely. The smart thing would be to call Detective Hoffman, tell her I'd found the entrance, let the professionals handle it. Campus security, the fire department, maybe even the state police. They had equipment, training, backup. They could map the tunnels properly, set up communication lines, do everything the safe and rational way. But I knew what would happen if they went down there unprepared. The voices would start calling, mimicking the searchers' loved ones, leading them away from each other and deeper into the maze. Some of them might make it out, others wouldn't. And Marcus, if he was still alive, might be lost forever while they tried to figure out what they were dealing with. I thought about Tony Turner trapped in those tunnels for 60 years, fighting against whatever darkness lived in the deep places.
I thought about the way he'd appeared when I needed him most, the calm authority in his voice when he told me to stop following the voices. He'd saved my life, but he'd done more than that. He'd shown me that some people chose to stand guard against the things that wanted to hurt others. Maybe it was time for me to make that choice. I went back to my car and opened the trunk. I'd brought everything I could think of on the flight, a powerful LED flashlight with extra batteries, chalk for marking routes, rope, a first aid kit, emergency flares, even a hand crank radio in case I needed to signal for help. I'd learned from my first trip into those tunnels. This time, I was going prepared. I also brought something else. In the bottom of my backpack, wrapped in a towel, was my camera. I hadn't used it in three years, hadn't even taken it out of its case since the day I'd photographed the civil defense posters in the shelter. But if something happened to me down there, if I didn't make it back, I wanted there to be evidence, photos of the tunnels, documentation of what was really lurking beneath the campus. Maybe it would help the next person who had to make this choice. The sun had set completely by the time I finished checking my equipment. The campus was quieter now. Most students are either in their dorms or at the library. I could see lights in the engineering buildings windows, but the north side was dark and empty. Perfect conditions for someone to slip through a hidden entrance and disappear into the underground maze. I shouldered my backpack and walked back to the grate. My hands were shaking as I pulled it open, the metal hinges creaking in the night air. The concrete stairs descended into absolute darkness, just as they had three years ago. But this time, I wasn't going down out of curiosity. I was going down because someone needed help, and because I might be the only person who understood what was waiting in the dark. I turned on my flashlight and started down the steps. The beam cut through the blackness, illuminating the familiar concrete walls of the shelter. My footsteps echoed in the enclosed space, a hollow sound that reminded me of all the times I'd heard those same echoes bouncing back from stone passages that seemed to go on forever. The shelter looked exactly as I'd left it. Same metal tables, same folding chairs, same civil defense posters warning about nuclear attacks that never came. But there were new signs of disturbance. A backpack in the corner that didn't belong to me. Fresh footprints in the dust. A water bottle sitting on one of the tables. Marcus had been here. He'd made it this far, at least. I walked to the far wall where the opening led to the stone tunnels. The jagged hole in the concrete was just as I remembered it, a rough break that someone had made decades ago to connect the official shelter to the much older passages beyond. I shone my light through the opening and saw the hand-carved steps leading down into the bedrock. That was where the real danger started. That was where the voices lived, where something ancient and hungry waited for people like Marcus, people like me, people who couldn't resist the pull of hidden places and forgotten secrets. I checked my equipment one more time, made sure my chalk was easily accessible, verified that my backup batteries were secure. Then I ducked through the opening and began my descent into the stone tunnels beneath Riverside University. The steps felt the same under my feet, worn smooth by decades of use. The walls showed the same tool marks, the same evidence of careful excavation by people who'd worked these passages long before the university was built. But now I knew I wasn't alone down here. Somewhere in the maze ahead, Marcus was either still fighting to find his way out or he'd become part of whatever malevolent presence called these tunnels home. And somewhere else in the darkness, if I was lucky, Tony Turner was still standing guard.
